body:
The `ko` codebase has made some changes recently to make it more easily consumable as a library by other Go programs, mainly to support Skaffold (see https://github.com/google/ko/pull/348). This should also help goreleaser embed its logic, if it wanted to.

Happy to help however I can!

@developer-guy @imjasonh maybe a can help here. ~~The idea is replace `Docker` using `ko` right?~~

Can you give some guidance please?

I wouldn't say "replace", since `ko` can't do some of the things Docker can, if you specify a Dockerfile.

But it could be a useful simplification/optimization if your Dockerfile is just doing a `go build` and putting that binary in an image and setting it as the entrypoint.

We should probably start with how we imagine configuring the `ko` build in goreleaser.yml and what `ko` would do when various options are set.

issue.title: add ko support for building and pushing container images

labels.name: size/XS
labels.description: Denotes a PR that changes 0-9 lines, ignoring generated files.

issue.body:
Signed-off-by: Batuhan Apaydin batuhan.apaydin@trendyol.com
Co-authored-by: Furkan furkan.turkal@trendyol.com (@dentrax)
Co-authored-by: Erkan Zileli erkan.zileli@trendyol.com  (@erkanzileli) 

<!--

Hi, thanks for contributing!

Please make sure you read our CONTRIBUTING guide.

Also, add tests and the respective documentation changes as well.

-->


<!-- If applied, this commit will... -->

fix #2556 

<!-- Why is this change being made? -->

to add ko support for building and pushing container images 

<!-- # Provide links to any relevant tickets, URLs or other resources -->


<details>

<summary> Sample .goreleaser.yml </summary>

```YAML
# This is an example .goreleaser.yml file with some sensible defaults.
# Make sure to check the documentation at https://goreleaser.com
before:
  hooks:
    # You may remove this if you don't use go modules.
    - go mod tidy
builds:
  - env:
      - CGO_ENABLED=0
    goos:
      - linux
      - windows
      - darwin
    ldflags:
      - -s -w -X github.com/GoTurkiye/hello-world-cli/cmd.GitCommit={{ .Commit }} -X github.com/GoTurkiye/hello-world-cli/cmd.Version={{ .Version }}
archives:
  - replacements:
      darwin: Darwin
      linux: Linux
      windows: Windows
      386: i386
      amd64: x86_64
checksum:
  name_template: 'checksums.txt'
snapshot:
  name_template: "{{ incpatch .Version }}-next"
changelog:
  sort: asc
  filters:
    exclude:
      - '^docs:'
      - '^test:'
dockers:
  - image_templates: [ "ghcr.io/goturkiye/{{ .ProjectName }}"]
    goos: linux
    goarch: amd64
    use: ko  ## notice here


```

</details>

![Screen Shot 2021-10-07 at 00 05 18](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16693043/136283554-708bcca6-029a-44a9-8203-ae74435a3b53.png)
![Screen Shot 2021-10-07 at 00 04 09](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16693043/136283558-515513d5-9fbe-4f0b-aa27-2f12016a2dfe.png)

Looking forward.

body:
yep, we need to discuss this.

My understanding is: we should probably use ko as a lib.

We don't need to build the binaries again, we already have them. We just need to craft the manifest.

I did start looking into ko's source code, but I'm not sure there's an "easy api" for this. Would be nice to collaborate with folks over there to get this done.

On GoReleaser side, we should probably just add another pipe, as it won't share most of the docker settings... something like:

```yaml
manifests:
   - names:
     - imgname1
     - imgname2
     - etc
     baseImage: scratch
     id: default
     arches: [] # maybe?
```

at least, that's what I had in the back of my mind.

Happy to hear your ideas.

I think that format mostly makes sense to me for mvp. 

I'd assume baseImage could also take an "auto" value or maybe just unspecified default to use distroless since that is ko's default and is kind of nice to have the CA bundles in an otherwise scratch container.

It may also be interesting to have some sort of local mode integration. For example, generally ko uses the `KO_DOCKER_REPO=gcr.io/my-project` to upload to a Container Registry. To publish an image locally, you'd set that to `ko.local`.   

Another parameter would be the cosign repo. By default ko stores the sboms in the same repo as the container image, but this is configurable via `COSIGN_REPOSITORY=gcr.io/my-project/sboms`

ah that makes sense @bwagner5 , thanks for sharing.

What we need to figure out now is how to use KO as a library instead of a binary, so we can avoid building the binaries again...

> ah that makes sense @bwagner5 , thanks for sharing.
> 
> What we need to figure out now is how to use KO as a library instead of a binary, so we can avoid building the binaries again...

I'd be happy to help here in any way. 

The main entrypoints are [`pkg/build.NewGo`](https://pkg.go.dev/github.com/google/ko/pkg/build#NewGo) which takes options to configure how to build an image from source, and [`pkg/publish.NewDefault`](https://pkg.go.dev/github.com/google/ko/pkg/publish#NewDefault) which takes options to configure how to publish that image. There are also publishers to [write that image to the local Docker daemon](https://pkg.go.dev/github.com/google/ko/pkg/publish#NewDaemon), for instance.

There's some examples of this being [used in the Terraform Provider](https://github.com/chainguard-dev/terraform-provider-ko/blob/main/internal/provider/resource_ko_image.go#L180) and in [this toy repo that demonstrates using ko as a library](https://github.com/imjasonh/miniko).
